Hands-on 2 - DataVis with Advanced ggplot2

Published

January 20, 2023

Modified

January 21, 2023

1. OVERVIEW

This study explores data visualisation using Tidyverse package.

2. R PACKAGE REQUIRED

2.1 Load R Packages

Usage of the code chunk below :

p_load( ) - pacman - to load packages into R environment. This function will attempt to install the package from CRAN or pacman repository list if it is not installed.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, patchwork, ggthemes, hrbrthemes, ggrepel)

3. DATA PREPARATION

3.1 Acquire Data Source

This study will be based on fictitious data set provided with this lesson.

Highlights of the data set

  1. Year end examination grades of a cohort of primary 3 students from a local school.

  2. There are a total of seven attributes. Four of them are categorical data type and the other three are in continuous data type.

  • The categorical attributes are: ID, CLASS, GENDER and RACE.
  • The continuous attributes are: MATHS, ENGLISH and SCIENCE.

3.2 Import Data

3.2.1 Import Data

Involved two (2) steps : import and inspect imported data set.

Usage of the code chunk below :

read_csv( ) - readr - to read CSV file into a tibble.

problems( ) - readr - to reveal any parsing errors when importing the CSV file.

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")
Rows: 322 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
problems(exam_data)
# A tibble: 0 × 5
# … with 5 variables: row <int>, col <int>, expected <chr>, actual <chr>,
#   file <chr>

Show the code

Remarks :

No missing data.

4. DATA VISUALISATION

4.1 ??

Compare histogram by R Graphics and ggplot2 -

4.1.1 Plot with R Graphics

Usage of the code chunk below :

hist( ) - graphics - to compute a histogram.

Show the code 
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label(aes(label = ID), 
             hjust = .5, 
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")
Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

4.1.2 Plot with ggplot2

Usage of the code chunk below :

ggplot( ) - ggplot2 - to initialise a ggplot object.

  • geom_histogram( )

  • ggtitle( )

Show the code 
ggplot(data = exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "black", 
                 fill = "grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

Remarks :

ggplot2 allows to customise axis labels, title, grid lines.

4.2 Explore Functions in ggplot2

4.2.1 Create Base for a ggplot Object

text

-- initialise a ggplot Object

ggplot(data = exam_data)

-- introduce aesthetic mappings

Usage of the code chunk below :

aes( ) - ggplot2 - to visualise the attributes of the data.

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS))

4.2.2 Add Geometric Objects

text

4.2.2.1 plot bar chart

Usage of the code chunk below :

geom_bar( ) - ggplot2 - to makes the height of the bar proportional to the number of “MaTHS”.

use geom_col( ) if the bars need to represent values in the data. 
ggplot(data = exam_data, 
       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

7. REFERENCES

  • Hadley Wickham (2023) ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. Online 3rd edition.

  • Winston Chang (2013) R Graphics Cookbook 2nd edition. Online version.

  • Healy, Kieran (2019) Data Visualization: A practical introduction. Online version

  • Learning ggplot2 on Paper – Layer
